publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in Šorčuqduring T III Š 29.4

seg.seg: ... The king says: "(I am) not capable to make turn the firm resolution ...
... in order to (pay) honorable homage in the Vicitrapuṣpa [= having many-colored flowers] garden, be(decked) with flowers [and] garlands ...
... we ... If they will cut down lianas [and] tear off flowers, this will be an offence by them. From the country (they will be banned) ...
«we …» If they, however, chop lianas and scatter flowers, this will be an offence of theirs, and (they will be driven) off the land (?).
... All went out. After the passing of seven days the bedecked Vicitrapuṣpa garden ...
... the four learnèd princes Ulkāmukha, Katakarṇi, Hastinyāsa, [and] Nupūra ...
... Ulkāmukha says: || In [the tune] maittär || "Flutes resound, and the ... animals trumpet ...
... But which [is] this difference ... the clay ...
... they [= the four princes] tore off blue lotus [flowers]. Th(en) or: (After having heard/seen) that ...
the ... say: Stop there! Keep to the lord's order! ...
… say: «[Go] back!, act according to the command of the lord.» The princes …
... [the king] ordered them [= the princes] to be bound. Ulkāmukha says: "Now our own life is at risk. Not (can we expect mercy?) from [our] dear father ...
We, his own life, cannot be abandoned by [our] dear father!
... The executioners bo(und) the legs of the princes tightly resembling bits of waiki ...
... [the princes] were banned (from the country). Having seen that, a great lamenting voice was heard ...
Dies gesehen habend, wurde eine große Klagestimme gehört.
Having seen this, a great voice of lament was heard.
... (they came) to the cementery of ...vana. The princes say. || In [the tune] haridāsñe || We remember all ...
... we were (driven out?) by a lie. This ... of [our] father's, the king's ...

p.note: 742 proposes a passive reading and a 2.sg. predicate: "(You are) not capable of being made turn", in which case the following ought to be "by firm resolution". I think that the king rather speaks about the firm resolution of himself regarding the decision of being succeeded by his youngest son instead of the four elder brothers mentioned below. In order to bring about this incorrect succession, the four elder princes are in the following tricked into getting banned from the country.
This is still part of the king's speech regarding the ban on plucking flowers in the garden.

The name of the garden is both times spelled without virāma; since in terms borrowed from Sanskrit a word-final vowel is quite often respresented by -ä even in prose texts (cf. ), it is unnecessary to restore a virāma.
-k(·)mträ belongs to a 1.pl. middle Prs/Sub form.
Note the colloquial spellings ṣuk for ṣutk and konaṃts for kaunaṃts.

In the Tibetan version of the story the princes are named Ulkāmukha, Karakarṇa, Hastināyaka, and Nūpura, as per Sieg/Siegling, 373, fn. 14 with ref. to 11; the Sanskrit name of the third brother is transposed by Hasti-niyaṃsa by 8.

According to Sieg/Siegling, the meter has 4x12 (5/7) syllables, but then we get a caesura inside the vowel sandhi in a6; this problem is not solved by assuming a 7/5 variation, because the passage has eight syllables if k_use indeed starts pāda d. Note that the same tune has 4x14 syllables in another text.
ñc is no doubt part of a masc. nom.pl. form.

In the Tibetan parallel, the princes are at first condemned to death and then pardoned and banished on the words of the king's minsters; the same ministers who came up with the plan of getting rid of the princes in the first place.
-vaṃ is the end of a Sanskrit place name in -vana "grove".
Because of the meter, restoration to a middle form klāske(mträ) (as per Sieg/Siegling) is likely.
According to Sieg/Siegling, the meter has 4x14 (7/7) syllables.

Sieg/Siegling proposed the restoration (śānmya)mte, followed, e.g., by 185: "we were (bound) by a lie"; but unless we have a word play between the unknown waiki (b5) and waike 'lie' (b8), a more likely restoration is (lyutstsa)mte "we were (driven out) by a lie". The rest of this fragmentary line is mostly unclear. nrai ‘hell' seems to be a separable form, to which -°lyai may be part of an attributive gerundive.

list.item:
For the Tibetan parallel, see [[Roerich 1988]]: 9-10.

a1 [[Thomas 1954]]: 742 proposes a passive reading and a 2.sg. predicate: "(You are) not capable of being made turn", in which case the following ought to be "by firm resolution". I think that the king rather speaks about the firm resolution of himself regarding the decision of being succeeded by his youngest son instead of the four elder brothers mentioned below. In order to bring about this incorrect succession, the four elder princes are in the following tricked into getting banned from the country.

a2-3 This is still part of the king's speech regarding the ban on plucking flowers in the garden.

a3 -k(·)mträ belongs to a 1.pl. middle Prs/Sub form.

a5 In the Tibetan version of the story the princes are named Ulkāmukha, Karakarṇa, Hastināyaka, and Nūpura, as per Sieg/Siegling, [[TochSprR(B) II]]: 373, fn. 14 with ref. to [[Rockhill 1907]]: 11; the Sanskrit name of the third brother is transposed by Hasti-niyaṃsa by [[Roerich 1988]]: 8.

a5-a6 According to Sieg/Siegling, the meter has 4x12 (5/7) syllables, but then we get a caesura inside the vowel sandhi in a6; this problem is not solved by assuming a 7/5 variation, because the passage has eight syllables if k_use indeed starts pāda d. Note that the same tune has 4x14 syllables in another text.

b3 ñc is no doubt part of a masc. nom.pl. form.

b4ff. In the Tibetan parallel, the princes are at first condemned to death and then pardoned and banished on the words of the king's minsters; the same ministers who came up with the plan of getting rid of the princes in the first place.

b7 -vaṃ is the end of a Sanskrit place name in -vana "grove".

b7-b8 According to Sieg/Siegling, the meter has 4x14 (7/7) syllables.

b7 Because of the meter, restoration to a middle form klāske(mträ) (as per Sieg/Siegling) is likely.

b8 Sieg/Siegling proposed the restoration (śānmya)mte, followed, e.g., by [[Thomas 1957]]: 185: "we were (bound) by a lie"; but unless we have a word play between the unknown waiki (b5) and waike 'lie' (b8), a more likely restoration is (lyutstsa)mte "we were (driven out) by a lie". The rest of this fragmentary line is mostly unclear. nrai ‘hell' seems to be a separable form, to which -°lyai may be part of an attributive gerundive.

a2, a4 The name of the garden is both times spelled without virāma; since in terms borrowed from Sanskrit a word-final vowel is quite often respresented by -ä even in prose texts (cf. [[Malzahn 2012a]]), it is unnecessary to restore a virāma.

a4 Note the colloquial spellings ṣuk for ṣutk and konaṃts for kaunaṃts.

a1 /// (wa)lo w(e)ṣṣäṃ mā yātall(e) klautkästsi|kl(au)tkässi (– –) pr(ā)kre prat(iṃ) (– ·)m(·) (– –) – – – a2 /// wināṣṣälñeṣṣe yarkeśc|yarkeś vicitr(a)puṣpä werpiśken(e) pyapyaiṃ pässakäntasa yaitoṣ|y(ai)|(toṣ) a3 /// -k(·)mträ cai|cey ṅke laitkeṃ kautaṃ_(Pl.)|kautaṃ pyapyaiṃ taṃtsäskeṃ_(Sub.)|taṃtsäskeṃ sū ka ṣpä traṅko tākan-me_(Sg.)|tākan-me ypoymeṃ a4 /// (·)w(·) lateṃ poñc|poñcä || tumeṃ ṣukt|ṣuk kaunaṃts|konaṃts kätkorne yaitoṣ vicitrapuṣpä werpiśkaṣṣe ya- a5 /// -mane śtwer uweñ mñcuṣkanta|mcuṣkanta ulkāmukhe • katakarṇi • hastiny(ā)se • nupūra a6 /// ulkāmukhe weṣṣäṃ || maittärne || #M12# kalneṃ ploriyaṃ|ploryaṃ tane|tne ; pīyaṃ_(Prs.Pl.)|pīyaṃ lwāsa , ka- – (–) : #1a kä- a7 %11 #1b %12 /// – (– –) – – #1c k_use no wāki cwi|cwī ; iścemaṣṣa|=ścemaṣṣa /// %4 #1d b2 /// (·)s(·)·(·) uppālnta rässāre || tu /// b3 /// -ñc() weskeṃ aṣkār rai : pyāmtso säswentse yaitkor mñcuṣkanta|mcuṣk(a)nta ak(· –) – ka- b4 /// śanmästsi|(śan)mässi yātka-me • ulkāmukhe weṣṣäṃ rilyi wes ṣañ śaul mā āppantse b5 /// -ne caṇḍāli waikiññeṃ peṅkeṃmpa|peṅkeṃpa tasemane mñcuṣkantaṃts|mcuṣkantaṃts ckāckane ersaṅk śānmyare|ś(ā)|nmyare b6 /// lyutsante-me || tu lyelyakormeṃ orotstsa|orotsa kwasalñeṣṣa weśeñña klyauṣāte b7 /// -vaṃ erkenmasa || mñcuṣkanta|mcuṣkanta weskeṃ || haridāsñene || #M14# epiyac|epyac po wes , källāskemtär|klāske|(mträ) b8 ; %7 #1a %10 /// (– – –)mte , waikesa : #1b pātri lānte , ce k(·)a (– ; –) – nrai ka , (–) lyai – #1c (·)e ·e – – – %12 #1d

Lines Translation Pages
b6 Dies gesehen habend, wurde eine große Klagestimme gehört. 217

a1 ... The king says: "(I am) not capable to make turn the firm resolution ... a2 ... in order to (pay) honorable homage in the Vicitrapuṣpa [= having many-colored flowers] garden, be(decked) with flowers [and] garlands ... a3 ... we ... If they will cut down lianas [and] tear off flowers, this will be an offence by them. From the country (they will be banned) ... a4 ... All went out. After the passing of seven days the bedecked Vicitrapuṣpa garden ... a5 ... the four learnèd princes Ulkāmukha, Katakarṇi, Hastinyāsa, [and] Nupūra ... a6 ... Ulkāmukha says: || In [the tune] maittär || "Flutes resound, and the ... animals trumpet ... a7 ... But which [is] this difference ... the clay ... a8 ... b1 ... b2 ... they [= the four princes] tore off blue lotus [flowers]. Th(en) or: (After having heard/seen) that ... b3 the ... say: Stop there! Keep to the lord's order! ... b4 ... [the king] ordered them [= the princes] to be bound. Ulkāmukha says: "Now our own life is at risk. Not (can we expect mercy?) from [our] dear father ... b5 ... The executioners bo(und) the legs of the princes tightly resembling bits of waiki ... b6 ... [the princes] were banned (from the country). Having seen that, a great lamenting voice was heard ... b7 ... (they came) to the cementery of ...vana. The princes say. || In [the tune] haridāsñe || We remember all ... b8 ... we were (driven out?) by a lie. This ... of [our] father's, the king's ...
